Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the potential danger of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines by stating that they will become deadly a few months after administration.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient scientific evidence or support to substantiate the assertion that the antibodies created by mRNA vaccines cause deadly immune reactions resulting in lung damage.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the antibodies generated by mRNA vaccines will be deadly, without providing any substantial evidence or scientific basis for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores alternative explanations and fails to consider the extensive research and testing that has been conducted on COVID-19 vaccines to ensure their safety and efficacy.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the overwhelming scientific consensus that COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective, as supported by regulatory agencies, such as the CDC and WHO, and numerous studies.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on the opinions and statements of an anti-vaccine activist and doctor of osteopathic medicine, whose credibility and expertise may be questionable in the scientific community.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
